Award.AwardTitle: West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar 2015; October 10-11, 2015; University of California, San Diego (UCSD)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar 2015" that will be held on October 10 and 11, 2015, on the campus of the University of California-San Diego.

This conference is the twenty-third installment of the West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar (WCOAS), a series that annually brings together a diverse group of mathematicians whose primary research interests are in the theory of operator algebras. Some of the foci of the 2015 event are the following: the Elliott classification program for C*-algebras; rigidity for ergodic actions and von Neumann algebras; subfactors and their invariants; graph C*-algebras; free probability and its applications; quantum groups. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was awarded to the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) to host the 2015 edition of the West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar (WCOAS). The field of operator algebras was initiated by John von Neumann in the 1930s. Part of his motivation came from quantum mechanics, where (as opposed to classical mechanics) observables are operators on Hilbert spaces. Operator algebras are collections of observables which are closed under addition and multiplication. The simplest operator algebras are the algebras of n-by-n matrices, for some positive integer number n. As can already be seen in case the of matrices, operator algebras are rich, non-commutative mathematical objects: A times B is not necessarily equal to B times A. 

Since its inception, the field of operator algebras has developed dramatically with connections to ergodic theory, topological dynamics, topology, quantum information theory, and number theory. In addition, operator algebras provide the foundation of noncommutative geometry. As a result of these interactions, the field of operator algebras is a lively and central part of mathematics. Currently important topics of research in the area include: subfactors and their invariants, rigidity for ergodic actions and von Neumann algebras, free probability and its applications, classification of C*-algebras, and noncommutative geometry.

The West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar is the only annual conference in western North America that covers the breadth of operator algebras. This grant supported the 2015 edition held at UCSD between October 10-11, 2015. The conference started in the morning of Saturday, October 10th, and ended at 12:30pm on Sunday, October 11th. There were a total of 12 talks, 8 on Saturday and 4 on Sunday, of 40 minutes each. The conference featured presentations covering a wide range of current topics in operator algebras, including deformation/rigidity theory, free probability, subfactor theory, and C*-algebras. The conference was attended by 45 participants, the majority of whom were PhD students and postdoctoral researchers. Roughly two thirds of the participants were afilliated with universities in the Western US, who were thus exposed to some of the most exciting latest developments in operator algebras. The conference was very successful in contributing to the development of operator algebras in the Western US. Thus, it provided an avenue for researchers to present their work and for researchers in the Western US to learn of the latest developments in operator algebras, and fostered ties between UCSD and various universities in the Western US. In addition, the success of the meeting (held for the first time at UCSD) help strengthen the visibility of the operator algebras group at UCSD within the mathematical community. The balance of the grant was used to invite researchers to UCSD to disseminate their research, as well as to cover the costs of PhD students at UCSD to attending various conferences.
